page.title: 06The Wreck of The Amsterdam
page.content: In the muddy foreshore at Bulverhythe is sunk a Dutch East Indiaman named The Amsterdam.Only the ends of its ribs now show above the beach at very low tides.The ship has been there since 1749,and attempts are now being made to salvage her cargo and raise the hull for preservation and display. Many artefacts such as wine bottles, dressmaking pins and items of clothing have already been recovered,but much more remains in the mud as yet.Divers experienced in marine archaeology worked during the Summer of 1984,and are working now,in Summer 1985,but foresee at least a further year before all the ship's contents are recovered. When the ship was beached in a storm it quickly sank as the beach here was unexpectedly soft.The Dutch government owns the wreck,but most of the cost of recovery is paid for by sponsorship.
